column4: anyone have some ideas on how I can stop gpg from caching passwords?
I'm a little disturbed by that - I thought I was running a very minimal installation.
That was for Ubuntu 9.04 and below.
I can't see anything in that panel that looks like settings... (12.04 LTS here)
this is so silly. All I can find is a "Passwords and Keys" app. AFAIK I've only installed the bare gpg. I can't find anything that seems like it might be of use...
I am referring to Tools > Preferences.
I'm stuck with whatever garbage they replace Gnme with in 12.04.  I've got a UI bar on the left hand side with a "System Settings", and that's about it.

my point being that I can't find anything resembling what you describe. It's a clean install of 12.04 off branded media. The only thing that resembles what you describe is the "Password and Keys" tool. I can't find anything else.
a minute ago, I told you to open up Password and Keys, click on tools, click on preferences, and uncheck "Cache PGP passphrases"
there's nothing there but an editor for keyservers.
it does cache, which is why it is showing you the login keyrings.
the best I can do is run gpg with --no-use-agent. This works for me, but I cant expect users here to do this :(
having any more luck finding information than I am?
ty for the help.  Wasted too much effort on this already.
